description: From Middle English *tever, teapor, teafur, from Old English tēafor (“red, red lead, vermilion, purple; a material used in making salve; pigment, salve”), from Proto-West Germanic *taubr, from Proto-Germanic *taubrą (“magic, sorcery”). Cognate with Dutch toverij (“sorcery, witchcraft”), German Zauber (“magic”), Icelandic töfrar (“magic, spells”).

entries.meaning: A kind of ochre used for marking sheep in some parts of England.

description: From Middle English *teveren, from Old English tēofrian, *tīefran (“to mark in red or purple, colour; depict, portray”), from tēafor.

verbs.description: tiver (third-person singular simple present tivers, present participle tivering, simple past and past participle tivered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark with tiver, as sheep.
